overview: This subject focuses on inclusive youth mental health practices that promote equitable access and engagement for all young people experiencing mental ill-health. It provides a comprehensive overview of mental ill-health among diverse populations of young people, ranging from Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples, those from rural and remote regions, through to young people who identify as LGBTQIA+. Evidence-based interventions or models of care for responding to the needs of these groups are also considered.
ilo: Identify population groups who are marginalised
Summarise the underlying factors which contribute to marginalisation
Outline the impact of different forms of marginalisation on the development and maintenance of mental ill-health in young people
Illustrate key issues which affect access to services and treatment in marginalised populations
Describe a range of interventions that are appropriate for working with marginalised young people
generic_skills: Capacity to translate knowledge into practice
Ability to find, evaluate and use relevant information
Capacity for logical and independent thought

Inherent requirements (core participatio.content: Further details on how to seek academic adjustments can be found on the Student Equity and Disability Support website:http://services.unimelb.edu.au/student-equity/home

assessment.brief: Online Quizzes of learning content – two multiple choice quizzes with 10 questions each = 20 questions in total (1% per question)
Graded discussion board – posting fortnightly reflections on learning content and responding to fellow students, with a minimum of 7 posts in total

date_times.contact_hours: Online equivalent to 20 contact hours is made up of 10 hours of lectures and live consultation sessions, and 10 hours of asynchronous discussions and structured online tasks.
